description.narrative: Insatsen omfattar stöd till barn och ungdomar i den georgiska utbrytarrepubliken Abchazien inom områdena hälsa och utbildning, med fokus på barn och ungdomar på landsbygden, inklusive barn med funktionshinder.

The project supports children and youth in the Georgian breakaway region Abkhazia within the areas of health and education. The focus is upon rural children and youth in the rural areas, including children with disabilities.

sector.narrative: Multisector aid for basic social services

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: This is a summary of results achieved during the full programme period (2010-2015) and is mainly based on the final report. The project has developed well against the intended outcomes with a clear strengthening of social service to the local communities in Abkhazia. The knowledge and skills of the social service providers have also been strengthened through extensive capacity-development work. For example: • 6305 children benefited from the services provided by the Social Community Centers (SCC) during the projects duration. Services included the establishment of 17 school canteens, 46 pre-school groups, psychological support activities, peer education groups and vocational training. • Approximately 495 children of pre-school age have experienced increased opportunities for creative and cognitive development. The overwhelming majority of parents have stated that they noticed improvements in the creative and cognitive development of their children. • 204 SCC facilitators and teachers received disability sensitization training. The capacity of 25 community based Primary Helathcare Centeter (PHC) nurses was enhanced to ensure the expansion of their roles and functions for the provision of social services to children and parents. • 765 children in the target communities have greater access to primary healthcare through the PHCs. • 272 children living with disabilities have improved their health and educational outcomes through access to physical and psychological rehabilitation and social orientation opportunities. 120 children with disabilities benefit from regular services on a rotational basis. • 157 teachers have improved their knowledge on inclusive education • 2917 pregnant women/expectant couples and parents in 25 communities continuously provided with pre-natal counselling and support services related to child care and parenting best practices as well as environmental and public health protection. The programme thus reached most of the planned outcomes. Difficulties lie, however, in outcomes related to the sustainability of the SCCs, mainly due to the problematic political and socio-economic environment and the inability to work directly with de facto authorities. All of the school-canteens, most of the medical points and pre-school groups have been taken over by de facto authorities and schools and have thereby become sustainable. However, all the SCCs reportedly need further international assistance in order to sustain and further develop. Working with child protection issues also proved to be difficult in the target area due to the taboo nature of such topics. Therefore the activities related to protection issues had to be limited to basic awareness-raising campaigns for nurses working in the PHCs. Below you will find a more detailed account of the results achieved during 2013 - 2015, detailed reports from the period 2010 - 2013 were not recorded in TRAC as the system did not exist in its current form then. An unexpected result of the programme was the fact that the informal working group on education and child issues, created a platform for dialogue between the de facto authorities and the international community on substantial issues related to these areas. This in turn allowed for the development of a programme, by Unicef, on inclusive education and multi-language education, which is currently being implemented with EU funds.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
